An "ʔa+kaŋ" round classifier (FRUIT)+BONE compound set.  Change of ã>ɨ observed in some languages in 'head' is always attested under 'bone', as are odd palatalization processes such as in Araweté.  All HEAD1 forms copied to BONE1 and FRUIT2-- ZJO

compound of FRUIT2 (round thing classifier and SCRAPE~SCRATCH1. - NCP 
Most probably originally meant shave head and came to mean head in some languages and hair in Yuki. - NCP

In languages that show an ã>ɨ shift, the compounded form TIRED does not show this shift.  I take this as evidence that this sound change targeted the word for 'bone' after 'tired' was reinterpreted as not derivative from it, but, crucially, while 'head' was still interpreted as HAIR+BONE -- ZJO

probably meant inner ear, the word meaning deaf is formed from this root. - NCP

Probable borrowing from Cariban (/susu/, /huhu/ is a frequent Guianan Cariban word for 'breast' or 'milk'; Émérillon, and perhaps Wayãpi, are known to have borrowed Cariban words recently (cf. Françoise Rose on the plural marker /kom/). - SM

At present, I can't tell. Wayãpi and Émérillon aren't that far apart, so even if it happened at the time of the common ancestor, this wouldn't be very long ago (a few hundred years). But it is not clear where this ancestor was spoken: if in the same general area, the borrowing could have happened then; but if it was much more to the south, then this ancestor would not have been in contact with local Cariban languages (yet) and the borrowing would have to have happened independently in Wayãpi and in Émérillon.

So, in sum: I can't tell. My gut feeling is that the borrowing occurred at the time of the ancestor (why would both languages borrow a word for 'breast/milk'?), but it's only a gut feeling with nothing to support it. -SM

An "ẽ+po" ?+ROPE compound, where latter was originally some classifier-like element (appears in several other compounds); copied to ROPE1 -- ZJO

this is a GROIN + TOOTH compound; we have considered a number of other alternatives, including SHARP (i.e. prominence) + TOOTH. The GROIN + TOOTH compound is a little semantically expected, but the sound correspondences work out perfectly. The compound presumably is based on some notion of sex as eating, cutting, or piercing. See also discussion under PENIS 2.5. 

The compounds exhibit different phonological reductions of the two components: gliding of /o/ in /ako/ 'groin' or reduction of /ãj/ 'tooth'

The distinct BLACK1 and BLACK 1.5 sets reflect the fact that we are currently operating under the hypothesis that there are two different roots here, *tsun and *tun; this is connected to the unresolved question of the compound nature of DARK1&2. One one view DARK1 = edge + tun (BLACK); and DARK2 = pi + tsun (BLACK), where the origin of the first element is unclear, but may be related to the pi in RED. On this view we would explain the differences in the initial vowels (and in some cases the second vowels) in the DARK1&2 forms as due to leveling. -- LDM

An extensive discussion of the items in this cognate set have led to the following observations: TPN exhibits a root /ir/ 'separarse, desprenderse, desgrudarse' which  is the basis of /po+ir/ 'let go' (po = hand) (cf. PG, poi 'soltar') and /mbo+ir/ 'separate' (mo = causative). Some languages exhibit a 'doubly causativized' form of the latter. The question that has occupied us is whether are two cognate sets or one, in particular, whether there is one set based on the above set of forms and, in addition, a /mbo-'i/ (CAUS-small) set. This issue is raised by the fact that some languages have forms w/ and w/o a final r (in languages that preserve them), and also have forms w/ and w/o a glottal stop. We have decided to merge the two sets, pending discussion w/ Fran re: the seemingly distinct Eme forms -- LDM

An "(mbo)ʔir" set (most languages lost final /r/ and they exhibit the CAUS prefix); other languages show a reanalysis of /mboʔir/ as the root, and then recausativize it, as in Warazu -- ZJO

An "apaɾaɾ" set.  This appears to be a morphological derivation and so I did not label it as 'compound', but I made two sets because the presence of this form appears to correspond in interesting ways to subgrouping -- ZJO

maybe related to lie on a surface 3 in some way. - SM

The individual languages seem to vary a lot on how many stems there are, and on whether they are all "forms of the same stem" or independent verbs -- so it's not clear to me WHAT was innovated (longer forms from shorter forms? shorter forms from longer forms?) and whether the different stems are to be reconstructed as independent lexems ('characters') or as forms of the same lexeme ('subcharacters') -- /ap/ vs. /up/ vs. /aw/? /ap/ and /aw/ vs. /up/? /ap/, /aw/ and /up/ as one?...

So I'd treat the positional verbs with great care -- their history is potentially confusing.

A *sok set -- ZJO

There are complex issues affecting reflexes of PTG *ts (and possibly *tʃ), such as possible morphological conditioning of sound changes, that make precise determination of how modern forms in different daughter language relate to each other. It is clear, however, that there are forms like *tsok, *yotsok, *tsotsok. In the case of *yotsok, we get reflexes like zog in EME, contrasting with forms like sok (<*tsok)

A "βɨβɨk" set.  This is an old reduplicated version of "βɨk" TOUCH (see evidence for that in Tapirapé), and in many languages the word for 'sew' contains the last surviving reflex of the old TOUCH root, so all SEW forms in this row have been copied down to TOUCH.  I wanted it to count as evidence for subgrouping, so I considered it a compound  -- ZJO

A *tsen set referring to spilling, pouring, or the motion of liquids, crucially with a different final consonant than *tsem 'leave from, emerge.' The initial consonant is attested in Tembe in reflexivized forms and also in POK with *ichini. Many forms in this row show a reciprocalized stem beginning with the nasal allomorph of /jo-/ -- ZJO

A "poɾ" set. Icludes many causativized forms that mean throw (the majority) and a few that mean remove.
